This week's bar of the week isn't quite the one to stumble home from after the last round at 2, a.m.
In fact, it happens to be a unique put-of-town spot‘about thirty miles away in Annapolis,so somebody
should be in sufficient condition for the return drive.
The Maryland Inn, an:ksurrounding attractions, justify a long trip to the state capital. Located off
Church Circle on Main Street, the Inn actually has three separate facilities to choose from. One, the
Treaty of Paris, is strictly a restaurant; if you're interested in dining in Annapolis, you'd do better to go
down Main Street to the Auberge de France (reservations needed— or over to State Circle and the
Barrister).
The main feature of the Maryland Inn, however—the King of France Tavern—deserves an occasional.
visit from Baltimore. As the only top-line jazz night club in the area, the King of France regularly
brings in performers like Earl Hines, Charlie Byrd, and (sometimes) Dizzy Gillespie. With tables to the
immediate front and left of the stage, plus the bararea , about a hundred people usually crowd the
Tavern on weekends, all of them virtually ne,xt to the musicians. The small-club atmosphere is
intensified by the tradition of keeping quiet and listening during the show, a salutory practice broken
only by drunken legislators and excessive Singapore Slingers.
Covercharge for the shows average four dollars, and they don't turn over the house on weekday and
Sunday shows. The Tavern also operates a "Jazz Club" which offers various yearly membership rates
that eliminate cover charges and allow a certain number of guests to shows.
After the show finished around midnight, with four solid hours of music behind, you can repair to the
other section of the Maryland Inn, the Drummer's Lot. A comfortable, candle-lit taproom, the Drummer's
Lot is free of the touristes and plebes that infect the bars around the dock. It's a good place to have that
last round in.

Dr. John Money, professor of Medical Psychology and Pediatrics
at,
the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, is a world-renowned authority on
the subject of sex. He is the author of several books, including Sex
Errors of the Body and Man and Woman and Boy and Girl. Money has
also done notable work in developmental reading problems of children;
The News-Letter sent staff member Rhona Lyons to interview Dr.
Money -- here follows Part One of that discussion. Next week, in the
conclusion of the interview, political and social issues of national
interest will be covered.
How did you.become involved in problems of #
gender identity and sexual deviation?,
When I was a graduate student at Harvard,
there was a case of intersex
(hertnaphroditism) presented to the small
group I was a member of. It was a case, as
I know today, of a fifteen year-old with
androgen insensitivity. That meant that he had been born looking,like a girl, except
that somebody found two lumps in the
groin, decided they were testes and that
this person without a penis would have to
be raised up as a boy. That was some time
in the first year of life, when the parents
had signed the birth certificate as a female.
They were Oven some vague kind of
prognosis that nothing could be done at
the moment, but it could be done when he
got to be a teenager and started to go into
puberty. In retrospect, one can see that
this was a case of extremely bad
management. At puberty, he
grew
breasts instead of a male body shape. He
was in the hospital to see if anything could
be done for him. Thet remarkable thing about it was that in spite of the
handicap of
growing up without a penis, and in spite of the, shall we call it, the insult of a body
that
grew in female dimensions at puberty, he was quite persuaded in his self-understanding
that he was a boy, and he had the general outlook of a boy. Of course, he was
mortified
that he had no penis, but he certainly didn't act or behave like a girl. I took that
case as
a starting point and used the information, the principles that it demonstrated
as a basis
for a search of the literatu-re, medical and psychological, on hermaphroditism.
That
culminated in a term paper which itself became the basis of my PhD dissertation, which
was an extensive review of a century worth of medical literature and a detailed
case
work-up of ten cases of various different diagnostic types of hermaphroditism.
The
person that I worked closely with in getting those ten cases was Doctor Wilkins from
the
Pediatric Endocrine Clinic here at Johns Hopkins, which was the first one in the world,
and it happened also to be the world's leading center for birth defects of the sex organs
and the treatment of those children. I came down here for a visit to use the files and see
some of the patients and that ended up in an arrangement being made a couple of
years
later that I would come down here to work. That was 1951.
Have you encountered much opposition to your work? Do you have trouble getting
grunt money?
Well, back in those days nobody knew I existed, so I didn't get any opposition.
The..
more visibility one gets in anything to do with sex education or sex therapy or sex
research, then the more opposition develops. This happens to be a'very negative era, as
everybody knows, for all of science and research in the public mind. I do think that sex
research gets a little extra of that negative reaction. It makes a good whipping boy. For
instance, there's a small, media magazine that was first published in 1933 under the
name Sexology. It was a very serious attempt on the part of the publisher, who,-by the
way, was the man who first brought out Sports Illustrated, and also the very first of the
science fiction magazines and many others—it was a very serious attempt on his part to
provide elementary sexual information for blue-collar people. He subsidized the
magazine on the basis of his other ones. For more than an quarter of a century, it was
not possible to sell that magazine by subscription through the Federal mail because it
had sex on the cover and it was offensive to the Post Office to carry it. It had to be sold
at newsstands only, under the counter. As recently as this year, they finally decided to
change its name. The new name is Together. The 'reason for that was that some news
vendors in polite places, like drugstores and department stores, still will not put a
. magazine on sale if it has sex on the cover, and it doesn't matter what the contents are,
it's just the word itself. Well that's a straw in the wind that indicates how strong the
sexual taboo still reigns in our society.
You are often in the position of advising the parents of all infant with ambiguous
genitalia ill regard to whic.h sex they will raise their child as. What factors enter into your
counseling:'
Point number one is that you never assign the baby to be reared in the sex that it will

totally incapable of rehabilitation in. You never rear a baby in the sex that it will not
be able to function well in, especially in the sexual life of adulthood. So if the evidence

your senses is that this baby has no penis., then you never expect it to be raised as a
boy
because there .is no technique for creating an adequate penis by surgery. It's been
attempted. especially for a boy or man who loses his penis. What it produces is better
than nothing for him. but it still isn't a workable penis. It's okay for creating a bulge
in

his bathing suit. It may even be okay for passing me urine, but you never can get it so

How did you.become involved in problems of #
gender identity and sexual deviation?,

group I was a member of. It was a case, as
I know today, of a fifteen year-old with
androgen insensitivity. That meant that he had been born looking,like a girl, except
that somebody found two lumps in the
groin, decided they were testes and that
this person without a penis would have to
be raised up as a boy. That was some time
in the first year of life, when the parents

They were Oven some vague kind of
prognosis that nothing could be done at
the moment, but it could be done when he
got to be a teenager and started to go into
puberty. In retrospect, one can see that
this was a case of extremely bad
management. At puberty, he
grew
breasts instead of a male body shape. He
was in the hospital to see if anything could
be done for him. Thet remarkable thing about it was that in spite of the

growing up without a penis, and in spite of the, shall we call it, the insult of a body
that
grew in female dimensions at puberty, he was quite persuaded in his self-understanding

mortified
that he had no penis, but he certainly didn't act or behave like a girl. I took that

a starting point and used the information, the principles that it demonstrated
as a basis
for a search of the literatu-re, medical and psychological, on hermaphroditism.

case
work-up of ten cases of various different diagnostic types of hermaphroditism.

the
Pediatric Endocrine Clinic here at Johns Hopkins, which was the first one in the world,

later that I would come down here to work. That was 1951.
